item.title: Bank of England 'ready to act' as economy shrinks record 20%
item.description: Governor Andrew Bailey pledges action after the UK's economy sees its biggest monthly decline on record.

item.title: George Floyd: Trump 'generally' supports ending chokeholds for police
item.description: The US president comes out against neck restraints after the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

item.title: Black Lives Matter: Police impose conditions ahead of anti-racism protests
item.description: Restrictions come after last week's Black Lives Matter protests saw some scenes of violence and arrests.

item.title: Fawlty Towers: John Cleese attacks 'cowardly' BBC over episode's removal
item.description: An episode of the popular British sitcom was pulled by UKTV because it contains "racial slurs".

item.title: Ricky Valance: First Welshman to have solo UK Number One dies
item.description: The singer, who was the first Welshman to have a solo UK Number One single, had been in ill health.

item.title: Prince of Wales and Emmanuel Macron to meet on quarantine exempt visit
item.description: Charles and Camilla will be the first Royal Family members to hold a major event during lockdown.

item.title: JK Rowling: Sun newspaper criticised by abuse charities for article on ex-husband
item.description: The Sun says its article, and headline "I slapped JK and I'm not sorry", weren't meant to glorify abuse.

item.title: Coronavirus: How GPs are changing the way they work
item.description: Full PPE, 'red zones' and cleaning the room between patients are now part of everyday practice.

item.title: George Osborne to step down as Evening Standard editor
item.description: The former chancellor worked as the editor of the London newspaper for more than three years.

item.title: Coronavirus: Positive tests continue to fall in England, says ONS
item.description: One in 1,700 people are thought to be infected, based on 20,000 tests in households.

item.title: Hello Kitty founder Shintaro Tsuji steps down as CEO aged 92
item.description: Shintaro Tsuj steps down after six decades at the helm of the company that created the character.

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: The great housemate sex dilemma
item.description: How will housemates choose who gets to have sex under the new rules?

item.title: The peaceful protester falsely accused of burning the union jack
item.description: Why did people accuse this Black Lives Matter protester of trying to desecrate a war memorial?

item.title: Racism in the UK: 'I feel like an alien'
item.description: Four black men speak to the BBC's Ashley John-Baptiste about their experiences of racism in daily life.

item.title: Author Bernardine Evaristo: 'This is a history-making moment'
item.description: Author Bernardine Evaristo becomes the first black British woman to top the UK paperback fiction chart.

item.title: Coronavirus: Couple reunited after seven-week battle against disease
item.description: Denise and Guy were separated for seven weeks as he was being treated for coronavirus.

item.title: PlayStation 5: Sony games chief says PS5 offers a paradigm shift
item.description: Sony's gaming chief says fast loading times, 3D audio and a new controller will all enhance play.

item.title: Coronavirus: Domestic violence 'increases globally during lockdown'
item.description: The UN has described the worldwide increase in domestic abuse as a "shadow pandemic".

item.title: Coronavirus: How will launderettes come out in the wash?
item.description: Despite being an essential service, many launderette owners say their businesses are suffering during lockdown.

item.title: Quiz of the Week: Whose statue got dunked?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: The Papers: Race 'tensions rise' and Brexit border 'U-turn'
item.description: Friday's papers focus on UK anti-racism protests, and plans for post-Brexit border checks with the EU.

item.title: George Floyd death: The mental health impact
item.description: Black Londoners discuss the impact George Floyd's death in the US has had on them.

item.title: Coronavirus support bubble families prepare to reunite
item.description: Singletons look forward to hugging family members after months of no physical contact.

item.title: Coronavirus: What will a night out be like after lockdown?
item.description: Pubs, bars and clubs are having to change because of Covid-19. But what will a night out feel like?

item.title: Coronavirus: Three firms still positive despite the virus crisis
item.description: Few businesses are unscathed by the lockdown, but these firms can see light at the end of tunnel.

item.title: Coronavirus: What a shrinking economy means for Luton
item.description: Luton is one of the most vulnerable towns to the financial impact of coronavirus, says its council.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does a working 'test and trace' system look like?
item.description: Guernsey's "test, trace and isolate" system has led to a return to something resembling normality.

item.title: British Airways: A breakdown in trust?
item.description: British Airways is a firm in crisis, struggling with Covid-19 and in conflict with its employees.

item.title: King of Staten Island: 'There's comedy in the most difficult situations'
item.description: Pete Davidson and Judd Apatow tackle personal 9/11 trauma in their new film, King of Staten Island.

item.title: The hidden detectors looking for guns and knives
item.description: Walk-through systems that can detect weapons are being rolled out, using a combination of AI and radar.

item.title: Hong Kong: City of two masks faces a new crisis
item.description: A year after the protests began, amid a pandemic, Hong Kong faces another existential crisis. Will it survive?

item.title: Coronavirus: World From My Window sheds light on global lockdown
item.description: The story of Hiba, a pharmacist, is one of the many brought together in a global project.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could drive-in cinemas take off in the UK?
item.description: Watching films from the front seat of the car has never really taken off in the UK - could lockdown change that?

item.title: George Floyd: The personal cost of filming police brutality
item.description: For bystanders who film acts of police violence, sharing their video can be a life-changing moment.

item.title: Premier League players to wear 'Black Lives Matter' on shirts
item.description: Premier League players' names will be replaced on the back of their shirts with 'Black Lives Matter' for the first 12 matches of the restarted season.

item.title: 'Sad day in the history of rugby' - RPA accuses clubs as pay row escalates
item.description: The English players' union says it is a "sad day in the history of rugby" as the row between players and Premiership clubs over pay escalates.

item.title: Carberry has 'no expectations' of ECB on fight against racism
item.description: Michael Carberry does not "expect anything" from the England and Wales Cricket Board in the fight against racism, which he says is "rife" in the sport.

item.title: Saturday's gossip: Juve ready to sell Ramsey
item.description: Juventus put Aaron Ramsey up for sale, Barcelona deny talks with Manchester United over Ansu Fati, Everton face big loss on Morgan Schneiderlin, plus more.

item.title: Japan, Singapore, Azerbaijan GPs cancelled
item.description: This year's Japanese, Singapore and Azerbaijan grands prix are cancelled because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: NFL pledges $250m to help combat systemic racism in US
item.description: The NFL pledges $250m (£198m) over a 10-year period to help combat systemic racism in the United States.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is a recession?
item.description: The world faces the worst recession for 80 years. But what does that mean?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Nine million people have accessed the scheme, which will move to its next phase in July.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing in England aimed at helping single people cut off from family and friends.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are going back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work in England?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, bars, cafes and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Pubs and restaurants in England are expected to reopen in July, but can I meet a friend for a meal?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: The first "support bubble" of people who can meet indoors has been announced in England.

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: Five unanswered questions on the travel quarantine rules
item.description: Travellers to the UK now have to self-isolate for 14 days. But how will the rules work in practice?

item.title: When can I ride an e-scooter legally?
item.description: With people told to avoid public transport, the government's hoping to trial e-scooter rental schemes.

item.title: What happened to plans to give laptops to pupils at home? And other questions
item.description: Questions about the the return to school, and other coronavirus topics

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: Should I go to university this year?
item.description: Will students have online or face-to-face learning this autumn, and will they still have to pay full fees?

item.title: Can thermal cameras help spot coronavirus?
item.description: The devices allow a person's temperature to be checked from a distance, but are not always reliable.

item.title: Coronavirus and face coverings: the correct way to wear them
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: What shops will open next?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England from Monday, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the chance of going on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus: Saffron Walden dentist shows new appointment routine
item.description: Join us on a walk through a dental surgery to show what you might face at your next appointment.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why are international comparisons difficult?
item.description: Should you be comparing Covid-19 statistics between countries?

item.title: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are becoming compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: A surprise lockdown apology from my ex
item.description: Have the long hours of isolation during coronavirus lockdown led people to reflect on failed relationships?
